title: FA chairman Greg Clarke among those asking for stricter racism punishments from Uefa following England abuse in Bulgaria
text:
Greg Clarke, the Football Association chairman, said England's players had endured "one of the most appalling nights I've seen in football" as Uefa faced calls to expel Bulgaria from Euro 2020 .

Clarke hailed the team's tough and dignified response in twice stopping the match during monkey chants by Far Right Bulgarian hooligans, adding that the time was now coming for stricter punishments from Uefa.

A host of anti-discrimination leaders remain hugely critical of Uefa after their partial stadium ban on Bulgaria failed to have any impact on reducing racism at Monday's match. “It’s now time for Uefa to step up and show some leadership," Kick It Out said, adding that "Uefa’s sanctions are not fit for purpose". "If Uefa care at all about tackling discrimination – and if the Equal Game campaign means anything – then points deductions and tournament expulsion must follow," the charity added.

Manager Gareth Southgate and his captain Harry Kane twice came close to leading the team off entirely, initially after Tyrone Mings raised the alarm just 22 minutes into the one-sided victory in Sofia. After facing monkey chants, Mings screamed at officials to intervene, shouting: "Hey, did you hear that?"

Clarke, who described how even the backroom staff had appeared visibly upset by the chanting, said afterwards: "I mean it’s probably one of the most appalling nights I’ve seen in football."
